Pit_Observation.pitNotes: 15 meters above the crown of a previous SS-N-R2-D2-O

Pit_Observation.activities: Recent avalanche activity on different slopes;
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: All, "very wet," slush layers were various old/new interfaces. This would indicate pooling water. Water was not in fact pooling or percolating down into the snowpack. These interfaces were simply melting quickly when exposed to the warm ambient temperature and solar radiation. If you kept carving the outer layer of the pit away, you could get to moist grains before they would quickly melt and turn into slush. After the negative deep tap test, I inserted my shovel as a modified shovel shear test. The column, "Popped," out as a sudden planer very easy result at the Early February Crust.

Pit_Observation.activities: Ski tracks on slope;
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Free water has made its way down to the 3/9 interface @29cm down. This crust has acted as a barrier keeping the snow below dry/moist.

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Loose wet avalanches on east-southerly aspects today.

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: -dust layer prominent throughout pit @ 130-143 -surprised to see only 10cm of facets at the bottom of this snowpack, I would be curious to dig elsewhere on this slope to see if the structure found in this pit is an isolated instance, illustrative of spatial variability, or if this is the prevailing structure of the slope -anecdotally it has felt like a warm winter in Breck, but I would still be surprised if S facing slopes are healing

Pit_Observation.activities: Poor pit location;
Recent avalanche activity on different slopes; We skied slope; Poor pit location;
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: We chose a poor pit location under Liberty Bell that is likely not representative of other start zones. We found frozen LW avalanche debris at the bottom of our pit. The LW cycle that deposited this debris likely corresponds with the formation of the Early February Crust observed throughout much of the range. Any stability tests in this pit will not likely be representative of the strength of this interface on other slopes.

Pit_Observation.activities: Pit dug in a Ski Area; Pit is representative of backcountry; Collapsing, localized; Cracking; Ski tracks on slope; We skied slope;
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: IMPORTANT: 0 cm is the top of the snowpack in this profile! SNOW DEPTH: 330+ cm, probe does not hit the bottom - Observations of extreme unstability at this location in the morning, but things have improved quite a bit throughout the course of the day, with warm temps - Still quite unstable, things have not "healed" - Heavy and wet new snow, which is wind drifted at this location - Around 3 pm things started to freeze up again - may further help to stabalize the surface slabs - Hopefully a lot of new snow coming up this week - could be a dangerous week potentially

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: THIS FULL PIT IS 100 YARDS FORM THE CROWN PROFILE ON SAME DAY, WE WERE LOOKING FOR THE INTERFACE FAILURE @47CM, GOAL WAS TO RECREAT A FAILURE AT THAT LAYER AND IDENTIFY ANY WEAKNESS IN SNOPACK. WE FOUND NO CONCLUSIVE RESULTS.
